body: @navis I got it. Thank you.

Do you allow quoting of column names? Are column names case-sensitive? I suggest you make the syntax as close to SQL as possible. That would also mean supporting quoting, and also using 'iif' rather than 'if'.

IIRC, the sequences returned by individual query runners are lazy and the actual query processing is done while the sequence is accumulated.  ChainedQueryExecutionRunner materializes the sequences so that the actual query processing happens in processing threads rather than http threads.
@nishantmonu51 is correct, we want to make sure processing happens within processing threads and not outside. We should definitely add a comment to explain the reason the materialization exists.
I've thought about that but why should it be? and if it should be, should it be done in some wrapper for runner, not in chained runner?

@julianhyde Currently it does not allow quoting and identifiers are case-sensitive. I've used double quote for string literal in #2836 but it would be better to change it single quote. I'll handle your comments in #2836.
I'm of course üëç on this one, but since I was involved I'd prefer if we get two other +1 on this one

@navis Thanks! We know that this expression language is going to be popular, and then we're going to wish that it as close to SQL as we can manage, otherwise we'll spend years trying to undo the differences.

@julianhyde we made the decision back in Druid 0.7 to have column names be case-sensitive to keep things simple implementation-wise. As far as I know SQL doesn't prescribe things to be case-insensitive for column names. For instance PostgreSQL is case-sensitive, but has it's SQL layer fold column names to lower-case, if not quoted. I think it would be worthwhile to have a similar behavior for Druid where any case-folding is left to the SQL layer doing the query translation.
:+1:  needs 1 more
@xvrl didn't changed case-sensitivity of identifiers and have no intention to do that, but possibly make an option for it.
@xvrl , what about now?
üëç

@xvrl I got that it's possible to use more threads than expected. But it seemed not like to use more direct memory because it will return single Sequence. And still, should it (materialization) be done explicitly by wrapping with something like MaterializingQueryRunner?
üëç
üëç
üëç

It's totally valid and workable to have case-sensitive identifiers and leave their case intact (i.e. not convert them to lower case as PostgreSQL does, or to upper case as Oracle does).

The only other thing is spaces in column names. If you allow space (and other punctuation) in column names then you need a way to use these in expressions. You might use double quotes (as Oracle and PostgreSQL), brackets (as SQL Server) or back-quotes (as MySQL).
A topN set aggregator would be nice too, even lacking counts, to get a representative set of high cardinality dimensions.

LGTM, It will be nice if we add some unit tests to cover the new class.
BTW IT is not a blocking issue.
@gauravkumar37 Thanks! Do you mind filling out the CLA @ http://druid.io/community/cla.html

Rebased on master. Because there has been so many changes in here about, I've make code barely compile. let's see the test results.
I'm having this problem too. Really hope someone knows how to fix this

@himanshug what are the performance implications of this? last time we tried mapdb we had a lot of problems with serde and it decreased ingestion rates substantially

Also, please remember to submit proposals for these types of changes

@himanshug 
No, I was not using shutdown. I just tried an overlord update and hit it.  
I think the race I hit was as follows - 
1) thread 1 and 2 both make a copy of pendingTasks 
2) thread 1 goes ahead and assigns the task, does putIfAbsent in tryAssignTasks, assigns the task and then finally remove the task from tryAssignTasks 
3) now thread 2 tries to assign the same task calls a tryAssignTasks.putIfAbsent which succeeds and it then tries to read the task payload which was earlier removed by thread 1.  

For the impact, i can confirm that the overlord was able to make progress and the task assignment also worked after this. I did not see any tasks failing after this. I noticed this when i saw a bunch of alert mails for this.
üëç
could you summarize all the changes in this PR in the description ?

@navis memory requirements would change for TopN's which uses the processing buffers, we have 1 processing buffer per processing thread, in case we use jetty threads instead of processing threads to accumulate sequence events in that processing buffer, we would need jetty threads \* number of segments being scanned by each query - processing buffers. 
does that makes sense ?

is there a standard way in jetty to collect metrics ? 
IIRC jetty can also be configured to collect stats about requests and sessions, 
wondering if exploring that would give us more detailed info & metrics about the jetty requests.

@fjy OffheapIncrementalIndex is not available for indexing[yet], but only optionally used in GroupBy queries which tries to optimize things by not sorting results in IncrementalIndex when possible (see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2571 ). with that, here are some numbers based on https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/benchmarks/src/main/java/io/druid/benchmark/IncrementalIndexAddRowsBenchmark.java .

OffheapIncrementalIndex with sortFacts = TRUE
Benchmark                                           Mode  Cnt   Score   Error  Units
OffheapIncrementalIndexRowsBenchmark.normalFloats   avgt   20  45.928 ¬± 1.221  us/op
OffheapIncrementalIndexRowsBenchmark.normalLongs    avgt   20  46.847 ¬± 2.234  us/op
OffheapIncrementalIndexRowsBenchmark.normalStrings  avgt   20  51.218 ¬± 1.358  us/op

OffheapIncrementalIndex with sortFacts = FALSE
Benchmark                                           Mode  Cnt   Score    Error  Units
OffheapIncrementalIndexRowsBenchmark.normalFloats   avgt    3  15.450 ¬±  9.408  us/op
OffheapIncrementalIndexRowsBenchmark.normalLongs    avgt    3  13.112 ¬±  1.487  us/op
OffheapIncrementalIndexRowsBenchmark.normalStrings  avgt    3  22.428 ¬± 24.327  us/op

OnheapIncrementalIndex with sortFacts = TRUE
Benchmark                                       Mode  Cnt   Score   Error  Units
IncrementalIndexAddRowsBenchmark.normalFloats   avgt  200  15.176 ¬± 0.625  us/op
IncrementalIndexAddRowsBenchmark.normalLongs    avgt  200  14.611 ¬± 0.570  us/op
IncrementalIndexAddRowsBenchmark.normalStrings  avgt  200  21.284 ¬± 0.394  us/op

note that in groupBy query processing sortFacts is TRUE only once in the very end before returning results to end user and with sortFacts = FALSE off-heap performance is not that bad.

this impl of off-heap is different from previous one as it does not serde any strings and keeps dimension dictionary on-heap wherease old impl tried to put everything off-heap.
note that on-heap version can not be created without very large heaps but off-heap version (even if 3x slower with sortFacts being true) allows larger groupBy queries with ability to upper bound on off-heap size.
hmmm, good to know that it does not have a bad impact but only error logs. null check is still the correct solution. will fix it soon.

@nishantmonu51 i don't think jetty has a standard way of giving number of open connections which is many times important as I want to know if number of open connections is more than the request handling threads and then requests are just waiting in jetty pool.

there seems to be StatisticsHandler in jetty that may be helpful here -  
http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/statistics-handler.html
org.eclipse.jetty.server.handler.StatisticsHandler
It also seems to have more info about Async requests, like number of requests dispatched/WaitState
Might be useful for the router jetty stats.
@xvrl , @drcrallen  ?
test should be fixed now, it was being too strict about ordering of segments from different partitions.

StatisticsHandler gives stats about requests once jetty starts "handling" them , things waiting to get assigned a handler thread wouldn't show up there. That is, it appears, there is no getXXX() on StatisticsHandler that gives me total number of open connections.
@xvrl I have tested this in our dogfood cluster and it seems to be working fine.

@xvrl didn't check that explicitly, although I assume mostly it was in the bitmap lookups, as I only removed one predicate creation per call to `getBitmapIndex` and don't think that would really be noticeable.

I'm seeing the following exception on the overlord when KafkaIndexTask tries to publish an empty segment:

```
2016-04-18T19:00:13,714 ERROR [qtp1943444495-51] com.sun.jersey.spi.container.ContainerResponse - The RuntimeException could not be mapped to a response, re-throwing to the HTTP container
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: segment set must not be empty
    at io.druid.metadata.IndexerSQLMetadataStorageCoordinator.announceHistoricalSegments(IndexerSQLMetadataStorageCoordinator.java:293) ~[classes/:?]
    at io.druid.indexing.common.actions.SegmentInsertAction.perform(SegmentInsertAction.java:104) ~[classes/:?]
    at io.druid.indexing.common.actions.SegmentInsertAction.perform(SegmentInsertAction.java:44) ~[classes/:?]
    at io.druid.indexing.common.actions.LocalTaskActionClient.submit(LocalTaskActionClient.java:64) ~[classes/:?]
```

I used to prevent this from happening by checking getActiveSegmentCount() which has now been removed, but probably it would be better anyway for the driver to handle empty segments.
üëç

This uses `<zookeeper-version>3.5.1-alpha</zookeeper-version>` which was mentioned in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2495 that we shouldn't use an alpha zookeeper version ~~üëé without a wider discussion on if an alpha version of ZK is desired.~~ see next comment
@nishantmonu51: modified QueryRunnerTestHelper and refactored FluentQueryRunnerBuiler not to take query as a constructor argument (also moved it to druid.io.processing from druid.io.server)

@drcrallen I think 2.10 is ok: http://search.maven.org/#artifactdetails%7Corg.apache.curator%7Capache-curator%7C2.10.0%7Cpom. Looks like it uses ZK 3.4.6. IIRC the 3.x Curators are the ones that use alpha ZKs.

So üëç on this and maybe we should also consider updating to ZK 3.4.8 (the stable release right now).
https://github.com/apache/curator/blob/apache-curator-2.10.0/pom.xml there it is. Must have mis-typed the version when I was looking around.
üëç on the latest changes.

@nishantmonu51 can you explain a little bit about the problem that you want to solve with this PR? It seems like at a high level, the problem is around the Broker having to maintain too much info about segments in memory?
Cool, looks good :+1:

@xvrl @nishantmonu51 thanks for the explanation, but I think I'm still missing something. Currently it's working like,

```
                       ResultMergeQR      ChainedExecutionQR(3)
                                         |- List (materialized) 
processing(memory) --- combining-seq  ---|- List (materialized)
                                         |- List (materialized)
```

But I'm suggesting that it would be ok with below, which can possibly occupy more threads but still not using more processing memory than above case.

```
                       ResultMergeQR    ChainedExecutionQR  HTTP-threads
processing(memory) --- combining-seq    --- sequence        --- *(>3)
```
üëç
@gianm is there any good reason to change the optimization level?
@xvrl Changing to interpreted mode (-1) for some reason? Experimentation? Working around (potentially not yet discovered) bugs in the optimizer?

and @himanshug says

Which means if we dedup jar list first, we can remove strange `existing` addressing 1. And to address 2, we should always delete jar file in `addSnapshotJarToClassPath()` before uploading. right?

@himanshug : addressed your comments.

@gianm I wonder how much we'll want to support this Rhino specific optimization flag given that in the future most of the Rhino code should be replaced with Nashorn whenever run in JDK 8. But if people think it's useful I don't have a strong objection.
Ok, I'll remove it, I just did it since it was easy to add but it sounds like there is no real use case for it.
removed.
üëç
üëç

it will happen when you end up allocating total direct BB size beyond what is specified in -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize .
we generally set that to 10 TB so that jvm continues to take up as much direct memory as available on the host. also we use a 64 bits jvm.

may be usage of socket appender increased your direct BB usage.
@himanshug that is my leading suspicion right now but I don't have the right kind of metrics to prove it yet.
This item is also here to help serve as a search target for anyone in the community who is hitting direct memory errors.
